title: Virtual Member Conversation: Mark Rothko and Felix Gonzalez-Torres
hero_caption: A gallery view (from left to right) of Rothko’s Untitled (Painting) (1953/54), No. 2/No. 7/No. 20, (1951), No. 2 (Blue, Red and Green) (Yellow, Red, Blue on Blue) (1953), and Untitled (Purple, White, and Red) (1953). The second and third painting are loans from a private collection.
short_description: Join Caitlin Haskell, Gary C. and Frances Comer Curator of Modern and Contemporary Art, and artist Dan Ramirez for a conversation about the paintings of Mark Rothko. This program accompanies an installation of five works by Rothko—three from the museum’s collection and two on loan—which are joined by Felix Gonzalez-Torres's “Untitled,” a key work by the pioneering conceptual artist.
list_description: Join curator Caitlin Haskell and artist Dan Ramirez for a conversation about the paintings of Mark Rothko.
description:
Join Caitlin Haskell, Gary C. and Frances Comer Curator of Modern and Contemporary Art, and artist Dan Ramirez for a conversation about the paintings of Mark Rothko. This program accompanies an installation of five works by Rothko—three from the museum’s collection and two on loan—which are joined by Felix Gonzalez-Torres's “Untitled,” a key work by the pioneering conceptual artist. Learn more about this installation.

About the Speaker

Dan Ramirez was born in Chicago in 1941. He received a BA from the University of Illinois at Chicago in 1975 and an MFA from the University of Chicago in 1977. Ramirez has taught at Columbia College, Chicago (1977–78), the University of Illinois at Chicago (1978–87), and the University of Wisconsin-Madison (1987-99). He is currently professor emeritus at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and was awarded a Pollock-Krasner Foundation Award in 2005.

Ramirez’s work has been exhibited in the United States as well as in Spain, Scotland, Mexico, Germany, and Italy. It has been featured in over 30 solo exhibitions since 1974 and can be found in numerous private, corporate, and public collections. Public collections include the Art Institute of Chicago; the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago; the David and Alfred Smart Gallery at the University of Chicago; the National Museum of Mexican Art, Chicago; the State of Illinois Collection at the James R. Thompson Center, Chicago; Illinois Benedictine College, Lisle; Moraine Valley Community College, Palos Hills, IL; Arkansas Arts Center, Little Rock; Indiana Museum of Art, Indianapolis; Daum Museum of Contemporary Art, Sedalia, MO; Museum of Contemporary Religious Art, St. Louis, MO; Sheldon Memorial Art Gallery, Lincoln, NE; San Antonio Museum of Art, TX; Madison Art Center, Madison, WI; and the Llorens Artigas Foundation, Gallifa, Spain.

Please note that all event times listed are in central time.

We recommend using a laptop or desktop computer and downloading the latest version of Zoom to enjoy this program. You can submit questions for the speakers in advance or during the program using the Google Form below.
